The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to the foundations of classical physics. However, the category of Hilbert spaces and operators has been used as a foundation only in a limited number of papers. This paper provides a categorical foundation of quantum theory that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are presented in a way that makes them accessible to a wide audience. The results are illustrated with a number of examples. The paper also provides a number of open problems.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, which, together with a genome assembly of a cnidarian parasite, provides a unique opportunity to study the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the biology of the Myxozoa and may have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism. (Less)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. In this study, we show that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the next 30 years, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for more research on the impacts of climate change on maize production and the need for more investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes and consequences of species coexistence. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in their inferred diets. Nonetheless, species differed in their proportional grass consumption, and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely across businesses, and many are financially fragile. We also find that many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. Finally, we assess the effects of the CARES Act loans relative to grants-based programs. Our results suggest that the CARES Act is likely to provide some relief to small businesses, but that it is not a panacea.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic by a combination of processes, such as nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris and the importance of the processes involved in its removal. It also provides a new perspective on the global distribution of plastic debris in the ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the solar system because it is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system in detail. In this study, we determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have cosmogenic nuclides that were produced in the interstellar medium. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides evidence that the solar system formed in a different environment than the rest of the universe. This study also provides evidence that the early solar system was not as pristine as previously thought.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals and find that it is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, a form of maternal care that has been shown to increase the amount of time spent with offspring. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of reproduction in mammals and the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care in humans. It also suggests that the reproductive output of mammals could be increased by increasing the amount of time spent with offspring. This could be accomplished by increasing the metabolic power of mothers or by increasing the amount of time that mothers spend caring for their offspring. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care in humans. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell types that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is designed to be both local and global in nature, and to be efficient in the transmission of information. The design of the communication network is important for the endothelium to efficiently control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially in the United States. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, including traditional signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is triggered by the opening of the activation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also shown that this residue is essential for the C-type inactivation gating and the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. Finally, we have shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter and opens the door to the development of new pharmacological tools.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the microbiome in the health of the host is well established, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not fully understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a diverse array of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are important contributors to the microbiome of herbivores and provide a foundation for future studies on the role of fungi in the health of herbivores.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon are poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate in social encounters, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low energy availability in high-anxious animals is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we present a synthesis strategy to design and fabricate structures that can realize arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized by a free-form inverse design approach, which allows the design of structures with complex geometries and material heterogeneity. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which enables the seamless integration of different materials with distinct behaviors. The structures are assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design and fabricate mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase SCD1. This mechanism of resistance is highly relevant to cancer, as it is frequently observed in human cancer, and the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a foundation for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular medicine. The most widely used class of antihypertensive drugs, the L-type calcium channel blockers, are associated with an increased risk of heart failure. In this study, we show that the three major classes of L-type calcium channel blockers activate STIM/ORAI channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is a mechanism of L-type calcium channel blocker-induced vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that caution should be exercised in the use of L-type calcium channel blockers in patients with advanced hypertension or cardiovascular remodeling. This study also provides a mechanism for the increased risk of heart failure associated with the use of L-type calcium channel blockers. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. The NWFP’s success in halting the decline of early-seral–associated bird species is also questionable, as the area of early-seral habitat has declined in some ecoregions. The NWFP’s success in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species is partly explained by the loss of older forests due to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is therefore essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We screened a library of 1,000 compounds and predicted their properties using a computational model. The best candidates were then tested in vitro and in vivo, and the best compound was found to be active against antibiotic-resistant strains of Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli. This work demonstrates the potential of computational design to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is able to adapt to different problems automatically. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to train and apply in practice.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and iconic groups of fishes on Earth. The lake has been described as a “living laboratory” for studying the evolution of adaptation and speciation. The lake is also a unique archive of climate change, with a continuous, 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind record of hydroclimate variability in the tropics, which shows that the lake has been a sensitive indicator of climate change. The record reveals a shift in climate around 800,000 years ago, which is consistent with the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, and shows that the lake has been a valuable archive of climate change over the past 1.3 My. The lake has been a critical component of the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock, providing novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species. The lake has also been a critical component of the evolution of human societies, providing a source of food and inspiration for art and myth.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, reduces the timing of the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning, compared with reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas impact hypothesis is based on the presence of magnetic grains and microspherules in the YDB sediments. However, the origin of the grains and microspherules is not known. We show that the grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin, and that the 187Os/188Os ratios of the grains and microspherules are similar to average upper continental crust, suggesting that the grains and microspherules are derived from the Earth. The presence of 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules in the YDB site is consistent with the impact hypothesis. The spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, and their 187Os/188Os ratios are similar to those of the spherules.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is still not fully understood. Here, we report that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deficiency in adult mice results in a wide range of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by infection. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the maintenance of tolerance in the adult organism.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes, and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. These results suggest that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of genes encoding these enzymes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of human culture. These findings have implications for the evolution of human culture and the origins of technology. They also suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of human culture.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated isoform. APOE is also highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is a major process in normal synapse turnover and pruning. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of a complement component in synapses, which may contribute to increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a new perspective on the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also provide a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a mystery. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the core material, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. This study shows that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the crystallization of the mantle. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and may lead to a better understanding of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of this drug for the brain are likely to be complex. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the addictive behaviors associated with chronic marijuana use. These findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is our species’ signature cognitive skill. However, the brain’s language system is difficult to study, and the mechanisms of language comprehension remain mysterious. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to reveal that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting the next word in a sentence are also the most accurate at predicting the brain’s responses to those sentences in the human brain. These results provide computational evidence that the human language system is fundamentally a predictive processor. Understanding how artificial neural networks can predict the brain’s responses to language is a major step toward understanding how the human brain processes language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that DL methods are often unstable, even when universal approximation properties guarantee the existence of stable neural networks (NNs). We address this paradox by demonstrating that there are cases where there exists a deterministic training algorithm that computes a NN with a given accuracy, but any such (even randomized) algorithm needs arbitrarily many training data. These results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a textbook example of how a lack of understanding of exponential growth can lead to disastrous policy decisions. This article discusses the design flaws of a classic psychological experiment that has been cited as a proof of the human inability to understand exponential growth. It is a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it continues to be a major public health problem in many parts of the world. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a rare human pathogen, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, and compared it with that of the well-studied Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings also suggest that the two leprosy bacilli have been evolving in parallel for thousands of years. This study provides a unique opportunity to understand the evolution of leprosy bacilli and may have implications for the development of new leprosy vaccines. (Less)

The evolution of entanglement is a fundamental question in quantum mechanics. It is also a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of entanglement in interacting systems. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a general framework to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit in nonintegrable systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed that is safe, effective, and easily administered. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. This vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that was codon-deoptimized to reduce the viral fitness. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, can be stored at 2–8 °C, and is temperature sensitive, which makes it suitable for mass vaccination programs. In addition, the vaccine candidate is safe in mice and hamsters and induces high levels of neutralizing antibodies. These properties, coupled with its potential for large-scale manufacturing, support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. However, there is no evidence that plague was transmitted by rats during the Black Death (1347–1353), the most devastating plague epidemic in history. Here, we present a mathematical model that fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the disease and the development of public health measures during the plague outbreaks.

The brain is the most complex and expensive organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn and adapt to our environment. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key driver of human behavior. However, the evolution of brain size is not a good proxy for the evolution of brain power because it does not take into account the number of neurons. This study shows that reptiles have small brains relative to body size but high neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells and may help to explain the variable roles of TRAP1 in cancer. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that the mechanical torque exerted by the filament network on ADF is critical for ADF’s ability to sever actin filaments. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our findings have implications for our understanding of ADF’s function in cells and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling cell migration and cell division.

Fructose is the most common sweetener in the Western diet, but its effects on brain and behavior are not well understood. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia happened independently. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences can be a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of emotions in social networks.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is the primary vehicle for the transfer of genetic information from the genome to the protein synthesis apparatus. The vast majority of mRNAs are translated, but the translation of a small subset of mRNAs is not. This phenomenon is known as alternative translation initiation (ATI), and it is thought to be the result of the ribosome encountering a modification in the mRNA sequence. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation. This finding suggests that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of translation and may contribute to the phenomenon of ATI. This work also provides a structural explanation for the observation that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling of being able to say that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities appears to be a key factor in healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. The aquatic optimum size is larger than the terrestrial size limit, and thus water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes. This study provides a quantitative test of the hypothesis that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of body size in general.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a cooler temperature in the nasal cavity, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here, we show that the common cold virus replicates more efficiently at the temperature found in the nasal cavity than at the temperature of the body core. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway, which is activated by the common cold virus.

The ability to sense the environment is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In bacteria, this process is often used to regulate motility, adhesion, and virulence. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This process is mediated by a chemosensory system that regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The mechanochemical model we propose for this system is based on the direct interaction of a chemosensory protein with the major pilin subunit of the type IV pili. This work demonstrates that type IV pili are not only used for motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding opens up new perspectives on the role of pili in bacterial physiology and evolution. It also provides a new example of a mechanochemical system that regulates the activity of a bacterial motility apparatus. (Less)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of agriculture and the environment. The results show that the use of pesticides is not well regulated, and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus responsible for the disease has spread to many animal species. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlights the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings suggest that the virus is circulating in deer, and that multiple human-to-deer transmission events have occurred. This study also provides a unique opportunity to study the evolution of the virus in a free-living animal population. These discoveries have implications for the future of the pandemic, and for the health of wildlife and humans. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower, the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the mechanisms that lead to the formation of these plaques are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is toxic to neurons, and that this toxicity is the primary driver of the early inflammatory response in AD.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. This suggests that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct intermediates are involved. This study adds to the list of proteins that fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The study also provides a new method for studying folding, which is expected to be useful for other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Less)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of action is the production of proinflammatory cytokines. In this study, we demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore the immune system function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This strategy could be used in the future to develop new therapeutic strategies for other immune-mediated diseases.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental property of the planet, but a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of the biosphere and its components. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system evolves in such a way that the rate of change of the system’s activity is approximately equal to the rate of change of the driving force. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a critical state, in which the system’s activity is constant. The critical state is a hallmark of SOC systems, and the existence of a critical state is a necessary condition for SOC behavior. In this paper, we present a continuous model of SOC, which is a scaling limit of the well-known sandpile model. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune, and its electronic and optical properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic and optical properties can be tuned, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its properties can be tuned, by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest to the scientific community and the agricultural industry. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are derived from the legume plant Medicago truncatula. These peptides are highly diverse in sequence, and some of them exhibit potent antifungal activity in vitro and in vivo. The structural architecture of the peptide is unique, and it binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The antifungal activity of the peptide is attributed to its ability to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane, followed by the accumulation of the peptide in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide and opens up a new avenue for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of species. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic after being transferred to the female reproductive tract, and we identify female-derived proteins that associate with sperm. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. These insights will be critical for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of species.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for the clotting system. It is also important for the hemostatic system, which prevents bleeding. VWF is secreted from the endothelium, where it is normally in a complex with the long form of VWF, VWF multimerin (VWF:MV), and other proteins. In the clotting system, VWF is in a different complex with VWF:MV and ADAMTS13. In the hemostatic system, VWF is in a complex with platelets. In VWD, the hemostatic function of VWF is impaired. We show that the A1 domain of VWF is important for the hemostatic function of VWF, and that it is also important for the clotting function. We also show that the hemostatic function of VWF can be switched on and off by force. This is important for understanding VWD and for developing therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to advance the field of microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing, China, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth, as it is a key factor in the evolution of the biosphere. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for understanding the evolution of the atmosphere, which in turn is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. This study presents a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria. The results of this study provide evidence that the temperature of the surface of the Earth has decreased over geological time. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of the atmosphere, which in turn is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. This study demonstrates the value of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. Ion channels are also involved in a wide range of diseases, including cardiac arrhythmia, epilepsy, and pain. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the immune system, as exemplified by the role of the BK channel in the regulation of T-cell activation. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the kidney, as exemplified by the role of the BK channel in the regulation of urine flow. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the eye, as exemplified by the role of the BK channel in the regulation of pupil size.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 500,000 deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has remained largely enigmatic. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, which may help to facilitate invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces, which, in turn, would have implications for the development of antimalarial strategies.

Diamond is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune, and its electronic and optical properties are not fully understood. Here, we use machine learning to predict the electronic and phonon properties of diamond under strain, and we validate the predictions by experiments. We find that diamond can be metallized, demetallized, and that its bandgap can be made direct or indirect, all under strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair, and that these effects are mediated by caspase-1/11. These findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of strategies to reduce disease severity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a top-down, left-corner manner, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a syntactic machine.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development, differentiation, and homeostasis. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the Wnt ligands and the Axin proteins. In this study, we show that the two Axin proteins are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers a differential responsiveness to the pathway. This subtle feature may be used to distinguish other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the search for new treatments is ongoing. One approach is to understand the neural circuits that control food intake and eating behavior. Here we report the identification of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating. This circuit is activated by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a region that is known to be involved in the regulation of feeding. We show that this circuit is activated by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, but not by direct stimulation of the dopamine system. This circuit is also activated by optogenetic stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, suggesting that it is not specific to electrical stimulation. Thus, we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating. This circuit may be a target for future therapeutic interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would therefore be a powerful tool for sustainable agriculture. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is uncertain. The region is undergoing rapid deforestation, and the causes of this trend are poorly understood. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation and improve our understanding of the role of local actors in forest management. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the experiment. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have had no effect in some communities. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately, but they are strongly linked. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and devastate economies. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the development of a subunit vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein is a promising approach. Here we report the design and characterization of an engineered RBD that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, and presentation of the protein on a virus-like particle can reduce disease severity in hamsters. These results suggest that this engineered RBD may be a useful component for a subunit vaccine against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We further demonstrate that these receptors are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKALS in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and open the way for further studies on the role of ALK/ALKALS in human cancer.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established hypothesis. However, the number of reconstructed Y. pestis genomes from the Neolithic period is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. Whereas HM predicted evaluations of Trump, across studies, social and prejudiced attitudes predicted evaluations of his democratic challengers: Clinton in 2016 and Biden in 2

The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to increase soil organic carbon (SOC) storage, but the extent to which this occurs in the United States is unknown. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage on grasslands. These results are important because the United States is the world’s largest producer of agricultural commodities, and the use of grasslands for intensive crop production is increasing. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a risk assessment framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates the zoonotic potential of wildlife viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment alongside those already known to be zoonotic. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a scientific basis for prioritizing research and public health interventions to prevent and control future outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of pollination and the role of color in animal–plant interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the role of women in shaping the modern European genetic landscape has been largely overlooked. Here we present the genome-wide genetic history of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that these women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some of them had artificial skull deformations, which may have been associated with the genetic ancestry they carried. Our results suggest that the genetic history of Europe is more complex than previously thought, and that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is responsible for a severe pneumonia with a high fatality rate. To understand how bat coronaviruses spread to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and transmission of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and effective approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. Our findings highlight the need for ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in other resource-scarce settings to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). In this study, we have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the role of the sliding clamp in regulating the processivity and stability of the replicative complex. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of the sliding clamp in the regulation of DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA. Here, we report the development of a ribozyme that can both synthesize and replicate RNA. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.
The clinical characteristics of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 are analyzed, and the therapeutic strategy is discussed.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-containing metabolites suggests a mechanism for the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the ability to control copper availability to competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a Mars sample is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at present-day Mars temperatures. The tridymitic mudstone at Marias Pass in Gale crater, Mars, is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a diagenetic product. The tridymitic mudstone is a potential source of tridymite for the Curiosity rover’s Mars Sample Return mission.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to affect the performance of forest ecosystems. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of classic Th1 cells and that this process requires the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and may represent a therapeutic target.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This will help us to understand the disease mechanisms and develop new therapies.

The ability of pathogens to use vectors to spread to new hosts is a major concern for public health. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, uses the antifreeze glycoprotein of its vector, the blacklegged tick, to alter the gut microbiota and more efficiently colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can use a vector’s natural defense mechanism to more effectively colonize its vector. It also provides a potential target for the development of new strategies to control the spread of vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the last major modification that led to the development of flight. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of flight and the evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to avoid being eaten by predators. In this study, we show that many vertebrates have the ability to change their color to be less visible to predators. This ability is called “chlorosis,” and it is found in many different groups of vertebrates, including fish, amphibians, and reptiles.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells that are able to maintain their stem cell properties are more likely to be able to metastasize and are therefore considered to be the cause of relapse and metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, a m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 is therefore a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world, and the first pocket Bible was made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study provides a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, but rather a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the development of new technologies for the production of parchment, such as the use of a frame to hold the skin in place. This study provides a new perspective on the production of the first pocket Bible. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction, and for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which is defined by the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle.

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment, and its homeostasis is essential for maintaining the health of the host. However, intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrated that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and may provide a new therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
