The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in the currently circulating virus, and several studies have suggested that it is associated with higher virus infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structures of the wild-type and mutant spikes and show that the mutant spike is more open, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. They also provide a resource for the development of structural models of the mutant spike. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical behavior of matter is the basis of all chemistry. It is therefore of utmost importance to understand the chemical properties of matter under pressure. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of matter change under pressure, and we provide a theoretical framework to understand these changes. Our results have important implications for the chemical behavior of matter under pressure, and they open the door to the development of new predictive models for the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that human demography, as well as climate, can have a strong influence on fire activity, and that this can have a significant impact on the carbon cycle. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally. This has implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results suggest that climate change may be less likely to drive global warming in the future than previously thought.

The symbiosis between animals and microbes is one of the most widespread and important interactions in nature. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example of this relationship. In this study, we show that the squid provides its symbiont with a single glycan, which is metabolized by the symbiont to enhance its ability to produce bioluminescence at night. This glycan is released by the squid’s immune cells just before dusk, a behavior that is established only in the mature symbiosis. This glycan is the first example of a nutrient that is specifically required for the persistence of a symbiont, and it is also the first example of a nutrient that is released by the host just before dusk. This study provides a new perspective on the role of nutrients in the symbiosis between animals and microbes. (Less)

We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe in 1347, and that it established itself in the rodent population over the next four centuries. We show that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was preceded by a series of climate-driven reintroductions, which took place over a period of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the bacterium was introduced into Europe several times, and that it was not established in Europe until the climate conditions were favorable for its spread.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem, but their population dynamics are poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a disease that has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids in the Northeast Pacific Ocean. The disease is caused by a densovirus that is transmitted by a vector, the sea star weevils, and is associated with rapid tissue degradation.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapeutic intervention is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We further demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. This study may therefore have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, allowing us to study the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened from different directions. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other island populations.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, an enzyme that is essential for growth on glycerol. The protein also interferes with the ability of a second small RNA to repress the expression of two other genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete with each other. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to control the expression of multiple genes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical for monitoring crop conditions and predicting crop yields. However, the information provided by crop experts is often difficult to use in quantitative analyses because of its subjective nature. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts across the country, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey data are stable over time, and can be used to monitor crop conditions and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to monitor and manage agricultural production.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a central executive that maintains information in working memory over short periods of time. Here we propose a different view of memory in the brain. We show that the brain can encode information in the form of adaptive changes in the excitability of neural circuits. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration rates increase with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that colder climates are considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results provide a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the organism. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition is accompanied by a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes, which is linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of plastids and the origin of parasitic lifestyles. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of the genome and gene regulation in the context of environmental change.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the attribution of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought to human influence. However, the model used in this study has a coarse horizontal resolution, which limits the ability to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts. This is an important limitation that should be addressed in future studies.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which these materials are formed are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the formation of this material and the date of the explosion.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light-harvesting pigments of oxygenic photosynthesis. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in R. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of cell survival and apoptosis. In this study, we investigated the roles of ASK1 in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. We found that ASK1 is required for the development of EAE, and that ASK1 signaling in microglia is critical for the development of EAE. ASK1 signaling in astrocytes also plays a role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting that ASK1 signaling in glial cells is phase specific. These findings suggest that ASK1 signaling in glial cells may be a potential therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm conditions has also increased. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the interaction of multiple genetic variants and environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms and may help to identify the targets of therapeutic interventions. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in a wide variety of countries around the world. This work also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, suggesting that the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads” may not be universally true. Taken together, these results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, but its physiological role is still not fully understood. Here, we report that mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 can cause a disease with hematological abnormalities, and that mutations in ORAI1 can cause a disease with hematological abnormalities and a reduced number of thrombocytes. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The bat is the most diverse mammal family, and bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein is a potent immunosuppressant. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunosuppressant. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the bat salivary gland in the transmission of viruses to other animals and humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft tumors. We also report a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a particularly sensitive cancer cell line to SHMT inhibition. These findings provide a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and suggest a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a hallmark of the disease. However, the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, and thus may be a general feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. This study provides a new perspective on the neuropathology of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have broad impact on the field of atomtronics. We believe that the 2D photonic crystal system is a promising platform for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We also believe that the device configuration presented here can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the study of these plants is important for understanding the origin of the flowering plants. The study of the aquatic flowering plants of the Cretaceous period is particularly important because it is the first time that flowering plants were found in an aquatic environment.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the genomes of five ancient viruses from archaeological remains, which are phylogenetically related to the most common human parvovirus B19V. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that the study of ancient viruses is possible, and that the archaeological record can be a valuable source of information. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and well-known indicators of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the time period for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the rate of sea level rise by 2100 could be as much as 10 cm/y. This acceleration is consistent with the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) AR5.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America since the 1970s, but that the increase has been greater for younger than for older adults. This pattern is seen across multiple datasets and definitions of pain, and is seen for those with less education but not for those with a bachelor’s degree. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is seen in the erosion of the working class in pain.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is critical for understanding the mechanisms of catalysis. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into the structure and dynamics of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the mechanism of the reaction and the role of the cofactor in the reaction pathway. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. In this study, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown promising activity against SARS-CoV, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. These results support further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS. The data also support the need for further development of antiviral treatments for other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools by changing the way teachers think about students. This is a major contribution to the literature on school discipline, which has been dominated by research on the negative effects of punitive discipline policies. The study also has implications for the broader literature on the role of teachers in students’ lives.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can be bypassed by the same transcriptional lesion bypass route, which is controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental and health impacts of the food system. This study demonstrates that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 61.8% in a university cafeteria. This is a large effect, and the results are robust to a range of analyses. These findings have implications for the food service industry and policy makers seeking to reduce the environmental and health impacts of the food system. They also provide a useful example of how nudging can be used to promote sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with its extracellular environment. It is therefore a critical target for cancer therapy. Here we use quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cells expressing different oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find that each oncogene has a different glycoproteome, but that the glycoproteome is also harmonized by common biological themes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with the immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may contribute to immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the world, and it is also a risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, hypoxic induction of CRFR1 and AQP4 is mediated by cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected

The problem of selective inference is that we have “cherry picked” a dataset and are now trying to assess the strength of the associations that we have found. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the development of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro, and the transplantation of vascular networks is limited by the lack of a vascular network that can be transplanted. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the development of vascular networks from nonvascular cells, such as fibroblasts, and that ETV2 can be used to generate vascular networks that can be transplanted into mice. These results provide a new approach for the development of vascular networks and the regeneration of organs.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTK biology. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and in the skin. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO β-cells. These findings established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of seasonal influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. They are composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our results suggest that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is a sequence-dependent process, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This process might also be a target for antiviral drugs.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the formation of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the United States, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This expansion has been driven by people, who have increased the number of wildfires and the area burned by over 40% in the last 20 y. This expansion has occurred despite the fact that lightning ignitions have not changed substantially over the same time period.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the perception of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also sheds light on the arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. Coral reefs are the most biodiverse marine ecosystems and provide valuable ecosystem services to millions of people worldwide. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching, which will ultimately lead to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and the collapse of coral reefs. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in a changing environment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors lead to the loss of the intestinal barrier, the imbalance of the microbiome, and the activation of a regenerative response. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also provide a model for studying the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States. The development of resistance to chemotherapy is a major obstacle to the treatment of breast cancer, and the identification of mechanisms of resistance may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is associated with the development of resistance to chemotherapy in breast cancer. Targeting ROR1 may therefore be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer.

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is difficult to reconcile with the timing of the onset of stratospheric ozone depletion. Here we show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong El Niño-like climate event, which plausibly contributed to the deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can influence climate and is a reminder that the climate system is sensitive to external forcing. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in regeneration, and it also suggests that the mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult nervous system are more similar than previously thought.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key parameter in the study of evolution. In this study, we use a population of wild plants to map the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution of recombination rates is strikingly similar to that observed in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the general pattern of recombination in eukaryotes may be more ancient than previously thought.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a small fraction of neurons is recorded by functional MRI. This activity is not representative of the total activity of the brain, and it is not known whether the observed fluctuations are related to the functioning of the brain. Here, we show that the resting brain can be organized in networks, which are related to the functioning of the brain in health and disease. We also show that the resting brain can be used to monitor the progression of disease, and that this information can be used to assess the efficacy of treatment.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery expands the number of 5′ modifications of mRNA in eukaryotes, and raises the possibility that the NAD-cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in yeast and other organisms.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist in whole blood and in monocytes of people with diabetes for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), the landmark study that established the benefits of intensive therapy. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic modifications at specific loci may be used as biomarkers of the effects of diabetes therapy. This may help to identify people who are likely to benefit from intensive therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of effective therapeutic options has led to a high mortality rate. In this study, we identified a novel role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. We found that FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This hypothesis should be tested in future studies.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these nitrogenous volatiles is poorly understood, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit are derived from the same pathway. This pathway is unique among the nitrogenous volatiles in other plant species, and the identification of this pathway in tomato fruit is a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds.

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance of species. First, more diverse communities are more likely to contain species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that biodiversity loss occurring independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a fundamental insight for understanding the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is divided into superficial and deep layers, and the superficial layers are subdivided into three distinct zones, which are thought to be involved in different aspects of the formation of spatial representations. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these layers is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC during free-moving behavior, and we found that the neurons in the three superficial layers are organized in a topographically structured manner, and that the neurons in each layer are organized in a topographically structured manner. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the superficial layers of MEC. They will help to elucidate the functional roles of these layers in the formation of spatial representations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can be involved in the regulation of flowering in a plant–plant interaction. We demonstrate that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering regulation and the role of flowering in plant–plant interactions. It also provides a new approach to study the evolution of flowering time. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we report the existence of a previously unknown type of nigral cell projection, the striosome–dendron bouquet, which is likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. We also show that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate, and their function is critical for maintaining normal heart rate and rhythm. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We found that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of normal SAN function. Our results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in regulating the electrical activity of SANCs and the function of the SAN. These findings have important implications for understanding the pathogenesis of arrhythmia disorders and for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, which are the main immune cells in the body.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a central executive that maintains information in working memory over short periods of time. Here we propose a different view of memory in the brain. We show that the brain can encode information in the form of adaptive changes in the excitability of neural circuits. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The ability to deliver biomolecules to plants is critical for the development of plant-based therapeutics and biotechnologies. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and we establish the design parameters that are important for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the development of plant-based therapeutics and biotechnologies.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides many ecosystem services to society. However, the coastal zone is also a highly vulnerable ecosystem, as it is often the first place where the impacts of human activities become apparent. In this study, we show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to the coastal zone. This is important because the coastal zone is often the most impacted part of the water body, and thus, the most vulnerable. Our findings suggest that coastal managers should consider the role of small streams in coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should focus on these smaller watersheds. This will help protect the coastal zone and the many ecosystem services it provides.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed homogeneity and isotropy of the universe.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. These changes in the EEG can be used to predict the onset of paroxysmal events, and the presence of these changes can render the microcircuit susceptible to overt paroxysmal events. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor. They also suggest that the NMDA receptor may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of paroxysmal events in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a large injection of organic matter–derived carbon, which likely contributed to the observed biodiversity loss. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which likely contributed to the observed global warming. These findings provide insights into the potential impacts of the current rapid climate change.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potential drug target for the treatment of human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key determinant of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, but in many other species, sex is determined by multiple alleles, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one of which determines female sex, interact to produce four possible sexes. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a new sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles in sex determination. (Less)

The retina is challenged by a number of reactive species that can damage photoreceptors and contribute to age-related macular degeneration. In this study, we show that the intracellular iron level in retinal pigment epithelial cells impacts the oxidation and degradation of a class of compounds that are implicated in the photodegradation of the retina. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to protect the retina from photodamage. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understand the functioning of the world’s food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of modularity in the feeding apparatus. This modularity has allowed the evolution of specialization on different prey types, and has helped to diversify the feeding strategies of siphonophores.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolutionary biology, but the fossil record is sparse and the evolutionary history of the hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves evidence for a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study provides new insights into the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human form. (Less)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft tumors. We also report a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a particularly sensitive cancer cell line to SHMT inhibition. These findings provide a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and suggest a potential therapeutic strategy for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamins, and thus their dietary vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is likely to improve their vitamin A status. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets in future research and policy.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. This alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
